sp.p: I have made that certain .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: But what motive could she have for such an act ?

div.stage: Hubbard looks wise .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: To Hubbard .You know more about this than would appear . What is it ?

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: I 'd rather not . It is too —

div.stage: Looks significantly at Mrs. Starkweather and Connie . ) — er — delicate .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: This affair has gone beyond all delicacy . What is it ?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: No ! No !

div.stage: Chalmers and Starkweather look at her with sudden suspicion .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Go on , Mr. Hubbard .

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: I 'd — I 'd rather not .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Savagely .I say go on .

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: With simulated reluctance .Last night — I saw — I was in Knox 's rooms —

lg.l: One moment ; please . Let him speak , but first send
Connie away .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: No one shall leave this room till the documents are produced . Margaret , give me the letters , and Connie can leave quietly , and even will Hubbard 's lips remain sealed . They will never breathe a word of whatever shameful thing his eyes saw . This I promise you .

div.stage: A pause , wherein he waits vainly for Margaret to make a decision . ) Go on , Hubbard .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Who is terror-stricken , and has been wavering .No ! Do n't ! I 'll tell . I 'll give you back the documents .

div.stage: All are expectant She wavers again , and steels herself to resolution . ) No ; I have n't them . Say all you have to say .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: You see . She has them . She said she would give them back .

div.stage: To Hubbard . ) Go on .

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: Last night —

sp.speaker: { Connie }
sp.p: Springing up .I wo n't stay !She rushes to left rear and finds door locked .Let me out ! Let me out ! { Mrs. Starkweather }

div.stage: Moaning and lying back in chair , legs stretched out and giving preliminary twitches and jerks of hysteria . ) I shall die ! I shall die ! I know I shall die !

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Sternly , to Connie .Go back to your mother .

sp.speaker: { Connie }
sp.p: Returning reluctantly to side of Mrs. Starkweather , sitting down beside her , and putting fingers in her own ears .I wo n't listen ! I wo n't listen !

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Sternly .Take your fingers down .

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: Hang it all , Chalmers , I wish I were out of this . I do n't want to testify .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Take your fingers down .

div.stage: Connie reluctantly removes her fingers . ) Now , Hubbard .

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: I protest . I am being dragged into this .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: You can n't help yourself now . You have cast black suspicions on my wife .

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: All right . She — Mrs. Chalmers visited Knox in his rooms last night . { Mrs. Starkweather }

div.stage: Bursting out . ) Oh ! Oh ! My Madge ! It is a lie ! A lie ! ( Kicks violently with her legs . ) ( Connie soothes her .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: You 've got to prove that , Hubbard . If you have made any mistake it will go hard with you .

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: Indicating Margaret .Look at her . Ask her .

div.stage: Chalmers looks at Margaret with growing suspicion .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Linda was with me . And Tommy . I had to see Mr. Knox on a very important matter . I went there in the machine . I took Linda and Tommy right into Mr. Knox 's room .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Relieved .Ah , that puts a different complexion on it .

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: That is not all . Mrs. Chalmers sent the maid and the boy down to the machine and remained .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Quickly .But only for a moment

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: Much longer — much , much longer . I know how long I was kicking my heels and waiting .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Desperately .I say it was but for a moment — a short moment .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Abruptly , to Hubbard .Where were you ?

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: In Knox 's bedroom . The fool had forgotten all about me . He was too delighted with his — er — new visitor .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: You said you saw .

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: The bedroom door was ajar . I opened it .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: What did you see ?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Appealing to Hubbard .Have you no mercy ? I say it was only a moment .

div.stage: Hubbard shrugs his shoulders .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: We 'll settle the length of that moment Tommy is here , and so is the maid . Connie , Margaret 's maid is here , is n't she ?Connie does not answer .Answer me !

sp.speaker: { Connie }
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: { Dobleman }. Ring for a maid and tell her to fetch Tommy and Mrs. Chalmer 's maid .

div.stage: Dobleman goes to desk and pushes button once .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: No ! Not Tommy !

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Looking shrewdly at Margaret , to Dobleman .Mrs. Chalmer 's maid will do .

div.stage: A knock is heard at left rear . Dobleman opens door and talks to maid . Closes door .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Lock it .

div.stage: Dobleman locks door .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Coming over to Margaret .So you , the immaculate one , have been playing fast and loose .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: You have no right to talk to me that way , Tom —

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: I am your husband .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: You have long since ceased being that .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: I mean just what you have in mind about yourself right now .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Madge , you are merely conjecturing . You know nothing against me .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: I know everything — and without evidence , if you please . I am a woman . It is your atmosphere . Faugh ! You have exhaled it for years . I doubt not that proofs , as you would call them , could have been easily obtained . But I was not interested . I had my boy . When he came , I gave you up , Tom . You did not seem to need me any more .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: And so , in retaliation , you took up with this fellow Knox .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: No , no . It is not true , Tom . I tell you it is not true .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: You were there , last night , in his rooms , alone — how long we shall soon find out —

div.stage: Knock is heard at left rear . Dobleman proceeds to unlock door . ) And now you have stolen your father 's private papers for your lover .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: He is not my lover .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: But you have acknowledged that you have the papers . For whom , save Knox , could you have stolen them ?

div.stage: Linda enters . She is white and strained , and looks at Margaret for some cue as to what she is to do .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: That is the woman .

div.stage: To Linda . ) Come here .
Linda advances reluctantly . ) Where were you last night ? You know what I mean .
She does not speak . ) Answer me .

sp.speaker: { Linda }
sp.p: I do n't know what you mean , sir — unless —

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Yes , that 's it . Go on .

sp.speaker: { Linda }
sp.p: But I do n't think you have any right to ask me such questions . What if I — if I did go out with my young man —

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: To Margaret .A very faithful young woman you 've got .

div.stage: Briskly , to the others . ) There 's nothing to be got out of her . Send for Tommy . Dobleman , ring the bell .
Dobleman starts to obey .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Stopping Dobleman .No , no ; not Tommy . Tell them , Linda .

div.stage: Linda looks appealingly at her .
Kindly . ) Do n't mind me . Tell them the truth .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Breaking in .The whole truth .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Yes , Linda , the whole truth .

div.stage: Linda , looking very woeful , nerves herself for the ordeal .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Never mind , Dobleman .

div.stage: To Linda . ) Very well . You were at Mr. Knox 's rooms last night , with your mistress and Tommy .

sp.speaker: { Linda }
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Your mistress sent you and Tommy out of the room .

sp.speaker: { Linda }
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: You waited in the machine .

sp.speaker: { Linda }
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Abruptly springing the point he has been working up to .How long ?

div.stage: Linda perceives the gist of the questioning just as she is opening her mouth to reply , and she does not speak .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: With deliberate calmness of despair .Half an hour — an hour — any length of time your shameful minds dictate . That will do , Linda . You can go .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: No you do n't . Stand over there to one side .

div.stage: To the others . ) The papers are in this room , and I shall keep my mind certain on that point .

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: I think I have shown the motive .

sp.speaker: { Connie }
sp.p: You are a beast !

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: You have n't told what you saw .

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: I saw them in each other 's arms — several times . Then I found the stolen documents where Knox had thrown them down . So I pocketed them and closed the door .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: How long after that did they remain together ?

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: Quite a time , quite a long time .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: And when you last saw them ?

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: They were in each other 's arms — quite enthusiastically , I may say , in each other 's arms .Chalmers is crushed .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: To Hubbard .You coward .

div.stage: Hubbard smiles .
To Starkweather . ) When are you going to call off this hound of yours ?

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: When I get the papers . You see what you 've been made to pay for them already . Now listen to me closely . Tom , you listen , too . You know the value of these letters . If they are not recovered they will precipitate a turn-over that means not merely money but control and power . I doubt that even you would be re-elected . So what we have heard in this room must be forgotten — absolutely forgotten . Do you understand ?

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: But it is adultery .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: It is not necessary for that word to be mentioned . The point is that everything must be as it was formerly .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Yes , I understand .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: To Margaret .You hear . Tom will make no trouble . Now give me the papers . They are mine , you know .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: It seems to me the people , who have been lied to , and cajoled , and stolen from , are the rightful owners , not you .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Are you doing this out of love for this — this man , this demagogue ?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: For the people , the children , the future .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Faugh ! Answer me .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Slowly .Almost I do not know . Almost I do not know .

div.stage: A knock is heard at left rear . Dobleman answers .

sp.speaker: { Dobleman }
sp.p: Looking at card Maid has given him , to Starkweather .Mr. Rutland .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Making an impatient gesture , then abruptly changing his mind , speaking grimly .Very well . Bring him in . I 've paid a lot for the Church , now we 'll see what the Church can do for me .

sp.speaker: { Connie }
sp.p: Impulsively crossing stage to Margaret , putting arms around her , and weeping .Please , please , Madge , give up the papers , and everything will be hushed up . You heard what father said . Think what it means to me if this scandal comes out . Father will hush it up . Not a soul will dare to breathe a word of it . Give him the papers .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Kissing her , shaking head , and setting her aside .No ; I can n't . But Connie , dearest —

div.stage: Connie pauses . ) It is not true , Connie . He — he is not my lover . Tell me that you believe me .

sp.speaker: { Connie }
sp.p: Caressing her .I do believe you . But wo n't you return the papers — for my sake ?

div.stage: A knock at door .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: I can n't .

div.stage: Enter Rutland .
Connie returns to take care of Mrs. Starkweather .

sp.speaker: { Rutland }
sp.p: Advances beamingly upon Starkweather .My , what a family gathering . I hastened on at once , my dear Mr. Starkweather , to thank you in person , ere you fled away to New York , for your generously splendid — yes , generously splendid — contribution —

div.stage: Here the strained situation dawns upon him , and he remains helplessly with mouth open , looking from one to another .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: A theft has been committed , Mr. Rutland . My daughter has stolen something very valuable from me — a package of private papers , so important — well , if she succeeds in making them public I shall be injured to such an extent financially that there wo n't be any more generously splendid donations for you or anybody else . I have done my best to persuade her to return what she has stolen . Now you try . Bring her to a realization of the madness of what she is doing .

sp.speaker: { Rutland }
sp.p: Quite at sea , hemming and hawing .As your spiritual adviser , Mrs. Chalmers — if this be true — I recommend — I suggest — I — ahem — I entreat —

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Please , Mr. Rutland , do n't be ridiculous . Father is only making a stalking horse out of you . Whatever I may have done , or not done , I believe I am doing right . The whole thing is infamous . The people have been lied to and robbed , and you are merely lending yourself to the infamy of perpetuating the lying and the robbing . If you persist in obeying my father 's orders — yes , orders — you will lead me to believe that you are actuated by desire for more of those generously splendid donations .Starkweather sneers .

sp.speaker: { Rutland }
sp.p: Embarrassed , hopelessly at sea .This is , I fear — ahem — too delicate a matter , Mr. Starkweather , for me to interfere . I would suggest that it be advisable for me to withdraw — ahem —

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Musingly .So the Church fails me , too .

div.stage: To Rutland . ) No , you shall stay right here .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Father , Tommy is down in the machine alone . Wo n't you let me go ?

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Give me the papers .Mrs. Starkweather rises and totters across to Margaret , moaning and whimpering .{ Mrs. Starkweather } Madge , Madge , it can n't be true . I do n't believe it . I know you have not done this awful thing . No daughter of mine could be guilty of such wickedness . I refuse to believe my ears —

div.stage: Mrs. Starkweather sinks suddenly on her knees before Margaret , with clasped hands , weeping hysterically .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Stepping to her side .Get up .

div.stage: Hesitates and thinks . ) No ; go on . She might listen to you .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Attempting to raise her mother .Do n't , mother , do n't . Please get up .Mrs. Starkweather resists her hysterically .You do n't understand , mother . Please , please , get up . { Mrs. Starkweather } Madge , I , your mother , implore you , on my bended knees . Give up the papers to your father , and I shall forget all I have heard . Think of the family name . I do n't believe it , not a word of it ; but think of the shame and disgrace . Think of me . Think of Connie , your sister . Think of Tommy . You 'll have your father in a terrible state . And you 'll kill me .Moaning and rolling her head .I 'm going to be sick . I know I am going to be sick .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Bending over mother and raising her , while Connie comes across stage to help support mother .Mother , you do not understand . More is at stake than the good name of the family or —Looking at Rutland .— God . You speak of Connie and Tommy . There are two millions of Connies and Tommys working as child laborers in the United States to-day . Think of them . And besides , mother , these are all lies you have heard . There is nothing between Mr. Knox and me . He is not my lover . I am not the — the shameful thing — these men have said I am .

sp.speaker: { Connie }
sp.p: Appealingly .Madge .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Appealingly .Connie . Trust me . I am right . I know I am right .

div.stage: Mrs. Starkweather , supported by Connie , moaning incoherently , is led back across stage to chair .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: { Margaret }, a few minutes ago , when you told me there was nothing between you and this man , you lied to me — lied to me as only a wicked woman can lie .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: It is clear that you believe the worst .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: There is nothing less than the worst to be believed . Besides , more heinous than your relations with this man is what you have done here in this room , stolen from me , and practically before my very eyes . Well , you have crossed your will with mine , and in affairs beyond your province . This is a man 's game in which you are attempting to play , and you shall take the consequences . Tom will apply for a divorce .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: That threat , at least , is without power .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: And by that means we can break Knox as effectually as by any other . That is one thing the good stupid people will not tolerate in a chosen representative . We will make such a scandal of it — { Mrs. Starkweather }

div.stage: Shocked . ) Anthony !

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Glancing irritably at his wife and continuing .Another thing . Being proven an adulterous woman , morally unfit for companionship with your child , your child will be taken away from you .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: No , no . That cannot be . I have done nothing wrong . No court , no fair-minded judge , would so decree on the evidence of a creature like that .

div.stage: Indicating Hubbard .

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: My evidence is supported . In an adjoining room were two men . I happen to know , because I placed them there . They were your father 's men at that . There is such a thing as seeing through a locked door . They saw .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: And they would swear to — to anything .

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: I doubt not they will know to what to swear .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Margaret , I have told you some , merely some , of the things I shall do . It is not too late . Return the papers , and everything will be forgotten .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: You would condone this — this adultery . You , who have just said that I was morally unfit to have my own boy , will permit me to retain him . I had never dreamed , father , that your own immorality would descend to such vile depths . Believing this shameful thing of me , you will forgive and forget it all for the sake of a few scraps of paper that stand for money , that stand for a license to rob and steal from the people . Is this your morality — money ?

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: I have my morality . It is not money . I am only a steward ; but so highly do I conceive the duties of my stewardship —

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Interrupting , bitterly .The thefts and lies and all common little sins like adulteries are not to stand in the way of your high duties — that the end hallows the means .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Shortly .Precisely .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: To Rutland .There is Jesuitism , Mr. Rutland . I would suggest that you , as my father 's spiritual adviser —

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Enough of this foolery . Give me the papers .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: I have n't them .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: What 's to be done , Hubbard ?

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: She has them . She has as much as acknowledged that they are not elsewhere in the room . She has not been out of the room . There is nothing to do but search her .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Nothing else remains to be done . Dobleman , and you , Hubbard , take her behind the screen . Strip her . Recover the papers .

div.stage: Dobleman is in a proper funk , but Hubbard betrays no unwillingness .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: No ; that I shall not permit . Hubbard shall have nothing to do with this .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: It is too late , Tom . You have stood by and allowed me to be stripped of everything else . A few clothes do not matter now . If I am to be stripped and searched by men , Mr. Hubbard will serve as well as any other man . Perhaps Mr. Rutland would like to lend his assistance .

sp.speaker: { Connie }
sp.p: Oh , Madge ! Give them up .

div.stage: Margaret shakes her head .
To Starkweather . ) Then let me search her , father .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: You are too willing . I do n't want volunteers . I doubt that I can trust you any more than your sister .

sp.speaker: { Connie }
sp.p: Let mother , then .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Sneering .Margaret could smuggle a steamer-trunk of documents past her .

sp.speaker: { Connie }
sp.p: But not the men , father ! Not the men !

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Why not ? She has shown herself dead to all shame .

div.stage: Imperatively . ) Dobleman !

sp.speaker: { Dobleman }
sp.p: Thinking his time has come , and almost dying .Y-y-yes , sir .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Call in the servants . { Mrs. Starkweather }

div.stage: Crying out in protest . ) Anthony !

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Would you prefer her to be searched by the men ? { Mrs. Starkweather }

div.stage: Subsiding . ) I shall die , I shall die . I know I shall die .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Dobleman . Ring for the servants .

div.stage: Dobleman , who has been hesitant , crosses to desk and pushes button , then returns toward door . ) Send in the maids and the housekeeper .
Linda , blindly desiring to be of some assistance , starts impulsively toward Margaret . ) Stand over there — in the corner .
Indicating right front .
Linda pauses irresolutely and Margaret nods to her to obey and smiles encouragement . Linda , protesting in every fiber of her , goes to right front .
A knock at right rear and Dobleman unlocks door , confers with maid , and closes and locks door .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: To Margaret .This is no time for trifling , nor for mawkish sentimentality . Return the papers or take the consequences .

div.stage: Margaret makes no answer .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: You have taken a hand in a man 's game , and you 've got to play it out or quit . Give up the papers .

div.stage: Margaret remains resolved and impassive .

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: Suavely .Allow me to point out , my dear Mrs. Chalmers , that you are not merely stealing from your father . You are playing the traitor to your class .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: And causing irreparable damage .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Firing up suddenly and pointing to Lincoln 's portraitI doubt not he caused irreparable damage when he freed the slaves and preserved the Union . Yet he recognized no classes . I 'd rather be a traitor to my class than to him .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Demagoguery . Demagoguery .

div.stage: A knock at right rear . Dobleman opens door . Enter Mrs. Middleton who is the housekeeper , followed by two Housemaids . They pause at rear . Housekeeper to the fore and looking expectantly at Starkweather . The Maids appear timid and frightened .

sp.speaker: { Housekeeper }
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Mrs. Middleton , you have the two maids to assist you . Take Mrs. Chalmers behind that screen there and search her . Strip all her clothes from her and make a careful search .Maids show perturbation .

sp.speaker: { Housekeeper }
sp.p: Self-possessed .Yes , sir . What am I to search for ?

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Papers , documents , anything unusual . Turn them over to me when you find them .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: In a sudden panic .This is monstrous ! This is monstrous !

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: So is your theft of the documents monstrous .

lg.stage: Appealing to the other men , ignoring Rutland and not considering Dobleman at all .
lg.l: You cowards ! Will you stand by and permit this thing to be done ?
Tom , have you one atom of manhood in you ?
{ Chalmers }
Return the papers , then .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Mr. Rutland —

sp.speaker: { Rutland }
sp.p: Very awkwardly and oilily .My dear Mrs. Chalmers . I assure you the whole circumstance is unfortunate . But you are so palpably in the wrong that I cannot interfere —Margaret turns from him in withering scorn .— That I cannot interfere .

sp.speaker: { Dobleman }
sp.p: Breaking down unexpectedly .I cannot stand it . I leave your employ , sir . It is outrageous . I resign now , at once . I cannot be a party to this .

div.stage: Striving to unlock door . ) I am going at once . You brutes ! You brutes !
Breaks into convulsive sobbings .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Ah , another lover , I see .

div.stage: Dobleman manages to unlock door and starts to open it .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: You fool ! Shut that door !

div.stage: Dobleman hesitates . ) Shut it !
Dobleman obeys . ) Lock it !
Dobleman obeys .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Smiling wistfully , benignantly .Thank you , Mr. Dobleman .

div.stage: To Starkweather . ) Father , you surely will not perpetrate this outrage , when I tell you , I swear to you —

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Interrupting .Return the documents then .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: I swear to you that I have n't them . You will not find them on me .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: You have lied to me about Knox , and I have no reason to believe you will not lie to me about this matter .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Steadily .If you do this thing you shall cease to be my father forever . You shall cease to exist so far as I am concerned .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: You have too much of my own will in you for you ever to forget whence it came . Mrs. Middleton , go ahead .

div.stage: Housekeeper , summoning Maids with her eyes , begins to advance on Margaret .

sp.speaker: { Connie }
sp.p: In a passion .Father , if you do this I shall never speak to you again .

div.stage: Breaks down weeping . ) ( Mrs. Starkweather , during following scene , has mild but continuous shuddering and weeping hysteria .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Briskly , looking at watch .I 've wasted enough time on this . Mrs. Middleton , proceed .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Wildly , backing away from Housekeeper .I will not tamely submit . I will resist , I promise you .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Use force , if necessary .

div.stage: The Maids are reluctant , but Housekeeper commands them with her eyes to close in on Margaret , and they obey .
Margaret backs away until she brings up against desk .

sp.speaker: { Housekeeper }
sp.p: Come , Mrs. Chalmers .

div.stage: Margaret stands trembling , but refuses to notice Housekeeper . ) ( Housekeeper places hand on Margaret 's arm .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Violently flinging the hand off , crying imperiously .Stand back !

div.stage: Housekeeper instinctively shrinks back , as do Maids . But it is only for the moment . They close in upon Margaret to seise her .
Crying frantically for help . ) Linda ! Linda !
Linda springs forward to help her mistress , but is caught and held struggling by Chalmers , who twists her arm and finally compels her to become quiet .

Margaret , struggling and resisting , is hustled across stage and behind screen , the Maids warming up to their work . One of them emerges from behind screen for the purpose of getting a chair , upon which Margaret is evidently forced to sit . The screen is of such height , that occasionally , when standing up and struggling , Margaret 's bare arms are visible above the top of it . Muttered exclamations are heard , and the voice of Housekeeper trying to persuade Margaret to sub-mit .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Abruptly , piteously .No ! No !The struggle becomes more violent , and the screen is overturned , disclosing Margaret seated on chair , partly undressed , and clutching an envelope in her hand which they are trying to force her to relinquish .{ Mrs. Starkweather }

div.stage: Crying wildly . ) Anthony ! They are taking her clothes off !
Renewed struggle of Linda with Chalmers at the sight .
Starkweather , calling Rutland to his assistance , stands screen up again , then , as an afterthought , pulls screen a little further away from Margaret .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: No ! No !

div.stage: Housekeeper appears triumphantly with envelope in her hand and hands it to Hubbard .

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: Immediately .That 's not it .

div.stage: Glances at address and starts . ) It 's addressed to Knox .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Tear it open . Read it .

div.stage: Hubbard tears envelope open . ) ( While this is going on , struggle behind screen is suspended .

lg.l: It is only a photograph — of
Mrs. Chalmers .

div.stage: Reading . ) “ For the future — Margaret . ”

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Thrusting Linda back to right front and striding up to Hubbard .Give it to me .Hubbard passes it to him , and he looks at it , crumples it in his hand , and grinds it under foot .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: That is not what we wanted , Mrs. Middleton . Go on with the search .

div.stage: The search goes on behind the screen without any further struggling . ) ( A pause , during which screen is occasionally agitated by the searchers removing Margaret 's garments .

sp.speaker: { Housekeeper }
sp.p: Appearing around corner of screen .I find nothing else , sir .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Is she stripped ?

sp.speaker: { Housekeeper }
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Every stitch ?

sp.speaker: { Housekeeper }
sp.p: Disappearing behind screen instead of answering for a pause , during which it is patent that the ultimate stitch is being removed , then reappearing .Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Nothing ?

sp.speaker: { Housekeeper }
sp.p: Nothing .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Throw out her clothes — everything .

div.stage: A confused mass of feminine apparel is tossed out , falling near Dobleman 's feet , who , in consequence , is hugely mortified and embarrassed .
Chalmers examines garments , then steps behind screen a moment , and reappears .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Nothing .

div.stage: Chalmers , Starkweather , and Hubbard gaze at each other dumbfoundedly .
The two Maids come out from behind screen and stand near door to right rear .
Starkweather is loath to believe , and steps to Margaret 's garments and overhauls them .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: To Chalmers , looking inquiringly toward screen .Are you sure ?

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Yes ; I made certain . She has n't them .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: To Housekeeper .Mrs. Middleton , examine those girls .

sp.speaker: { Housekeeper }
sp.p: Passing hands over dresses of Maids .No , sir .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: From behind screen , in a subdued , spiritless voice .May I dress — now ?

div.stage: Nobody answers . ) It — it is quite chilly .
Nobody answers . ) Will you let Linda come to me , please ?
Starkweather nods savagely to Linda , to obey . ) ( Linda crosses to garments , gathers them up , and disappears behind screen .

p.stage: Exit Housekeeper and the two Maids .

sp.speaker: { Dobleman }
sp.p: Hesitating , after closing door .Shall I lock it ?

div.stage: Starkweather does not answer , and Dobleman leaves door unlocked .

lg.l: May I take mother away ?
lg.stage: Starkweather , who is in a brown study , nods .
Connie assists Mrs. Starkweather to her feet .
lg.l: { Mrs. Starkweather }

div.stage: Staggering weakly , and sinking back into chair . ) Let me rest a moment , Connie . I 'll be better . ( To Starkweather , who takes no notice . ) Anthony , I am going to bed . This has been too much for me . I shall be sick . I shall never catch that train to-day .
Shudders and sighs , leans head back , closes eyes , and Connie fans her or administers smelling salts .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: To Hubbard .What 's to be done ?

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: Shrugging shoulders .I 'm all at sea . I had just left the letters with him , when Mrs. Chalmers entered the room . What 's become of them ? She has n't them , that 's certain .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: But why ? Why should she have taken them ?

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: Dryly , pointing to crumpled photograph on floor .It seems very clear to me .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: You think so ? You think so ?

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: I told you what I saw last night at his rooms . There is no other explanation .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Angrily .And that 's the sort he is — vaunting his moral superiority — mouthing phrases about theft — our theft — and himself the greatest thief of all , stealing the dearest and sacredest things —

div.stage: Margaret appears from behind screen , pinning on her hat . She is dressed , but somewhat in disarray , and Linda follows , pulling and touching and arranging . Margaret pauses near to Rutland , but does not seem to see him .

sp.speaker: { Rutland }
sp.p: Lamely .It is a sad happening — ahem — a sad happening . I am grieved , deeply grieved . I cannot tell you , Mrs. Chalmers , how grieved I am to have been compelled to be present at this — ahem — this unfortunate —

div.stage: Margaret withers him with a look and he awkwardly ceases .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: After this , father , there is one thing I shall do —

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Interrupting .Go to your lover , I suppose . { Margaret }Coldly .Have it that way if you choose .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: And take him what you have stolen —

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Arousing suddenly from brown study .But she has n't them on her . She has n't been out of the room . They are not in the room . Then where are they ?

div.stage: During the following , Margaret goes to the door , which Dobleman opens . She forces Linda to go out and herself pauses in open door to listen .

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: Uttering an exclamation of enlightenment , going rapidly across to window at left and raising it .It is not locked . It moves noiselessly . There 's the explanation .

div.stage: To Starkweather . ) While you were at the safe , with your back turned , she lifted the window , tossed the papers out to somebody waiting —
He sticks head and shoulders out of window , peers down , then brings head and shoulders back . ) — No ; they are not there . Somebody was waiting for them .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: But how should she know I had them ? You had only just recovered them ?

sp.speaker: { Hubbard }
sp.p: Did n't Knox know right away last night that I had taken them ? I took the up-elevator instead of the down when I heard him running along the hall . Trust him to let her know what had happened . She was the only one who could recover them for him . Else why did she come here so immediately this morning ? To steal the package , of course . And she had some one waiting outside . She tossed them out and closed the window —

div.stage: He closes window . ) — You notice it makes no sound .— and sat down again — all while your back was turned .

sp.speaker: { Starkweather }
sp.p: Margaret , is this true ?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Excitedly .Yes , the window . Why did n't you think of it before ? Of course , the window . He — somebody was waiting . They are gone now — miles and miles away . You will never get them . They are in his hands now . He will use them in his speech this afternoon .Laughs wildly .

div.stage: Suddenly changing her tone to mock meekness , subtle with defiance . ) May I go — now ?
Nobody answers , and she makes exit . ) ( A moments pause , during which Starkweather , Chalmers , and Hubbard look at each other in stupefaction .

div.head: ACT IV

stage.stage: Scene . Same as Act I . It is half past one of same day . Curtain discloses Knox seated at right front and waiting . He is dejected in attitude .

div.stage: Margaret enters from right rear , and advances to him . He rises awkwardly and shakes hands . She is very calm and self-possessed .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: I knew you would come . Strange that I had to send for you so soon after last night —

div.stage: With alarm and sudden change of manner . ) What is the matter ? You are sick . Your hand is cold .
She warms it in both of her hands .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: It is flame or freeze with me .

div.stage: Smiling . ) And I 'd rather flame .

lg.stage: Becoming aware that she is warming his hand .
lg.l: Sit down and tell me what is the matter .

div.stage: Leading him by the hand she seats him , at the same time seating herself .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Abruptly .After you left last night , Hubbard stole those documents back again .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Very matter-of-fact .Yes ; he was in your bedroom while I was there .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Startled .How do you know that ? Anyway , he did not know who you were .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Oh yes he did .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Angrily .And he has dared —?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Yes ; not two hours ago . He announced the fact before my father , my mother , Connie , the servants , everybody .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Rising to his feet and beginning to pace perturbedly up and down .The cur ! { Margaret }Quietly .I believe , among other things , I told him he was that myself .

div.stage: She laughs cynically . ) Oh , it was a pretty family party , I assure you . Mother said she did n't believe it — but that was only hysteria . Of course she believes it — the worst . So does Connie — everybody .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Stopping abruptly and looking at her horror-stricken .You do n't mean they charged ——?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: No ; I do n't mean that . I mean more . They did n't charge . They accepted it as a proven fact that I was guilty . That you were my — lover .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: On that man 's testimony ?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: He had two witnesses in an adjoining room .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Relieved .All the better . They can testify to nothing more than the truth , and the truth is not serious . In our case it is good , for we renounced each other .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: You do n't know these men . It is easy to guess that they have been well trained . They would swear to anything .

div.stage: She laughs bitterly . ) They are my father 's men , you know , his paid sleuth-hounds .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Collapsing in chair , holding head in hands , and groaning .How you must have suffered . What a terrible time , what a terrible time ! I can see it all — before everybody — your nearest and dearest . Ah , I could not understand , after our parting last night , why you should have sent for me today . But now I know .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: No you do n't , at all .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Ignoring her and again beginning to pace back and forth , thinking on his feet .What 's the difference ? I am ruined politically . Their scheme has worked out only too well . Gifford warned me , you warned me , everybody warned me . But I was a fool , blind — with a fool 's folly . There is nothing left but you now .

div.stage: He pauses , and the light of a new thought irradiates his face . ) Do you know , Margaret , I thank God it has happened as it has . What if my usefulness is destroyed ? There will be other men — other leaders . I but make way for another . The cause of the people can never be lost . And though I am driven from the fight , I am driven to you . We are driven together . It is fate . Again I thank God for it .
He approaches her and tries to clasp her in his arms , but she steps back .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Smiling sadly .Ah , now you flame . The tables are reversed . Last night it was I . We are fortunate that we choose diverse times for our moods — else there would be naught but one sweet melting mad disaster .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: But it is not as if we had done this thing deliberately and selfishly . We have renounced . We have struggled against it until we were beaten . And now we are driven together , not by our doing but Fate 's . After this affair this morning there is nothing for you but to come to me . And as for me , despite my best , I am finished . I have failed . As I told you , the papers are stolen . There will be no speech this afternoon .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Quietly .Yes there will .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Impossible . I would make a triple fool of myself . I would be unable to substantiate my charges .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: You will substantiate them . What a chain of theft it is . My father steals from the people . The documents that prove his stealing are stolen by Gherst . Hubbard steals them from you and returns them to my father . And I steal them from my father and pass them back to you . { Knox }Astounded .You ?— You ?—

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Yes ; this very morning . That was the cause of all the trouble . If I had n't stolen them nothing would have happened . Hubbard had just returned them to my father .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Profoundly touched .And you did this for me —?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Dear man , I did n't do it for you . I was n't brave enough . I should have given in . I do n't mind confessing that I started to do it for you , but it soon grew so terrible that I was afraid . It grew so terrible that had it been for you alone I should have surrendered . But out of the terror of it all I caught a wider vision , and all that you said last night rose before me . And I knew that you were right . I thought of all the people , and of the little children . I did it for them , after all . You speak for them . I stole the papers so that you could use them in speaking for the people . Do n't you see , dear man ?

div.stage: Changing to angry recollection . ) Do you know what they cost me ? Do you know what was done to me , to-day , this morning , in my father 's house ? I was shamed , humiliated , as I would never have dreamed it possible . Do you know what they did to me ? The servants were called in , and by them I was stripped before everybody — my family , Hubbard , the Reverend Mr. Rutland , the secretary , everybody .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Stunned .Stripped — you ?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Every stitch . My father commanded it

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Suddenly visioning the scene .My God !

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Recovering herself and speaking cynically , with a laugh at his shocked face .No ; it was not so bad as that . There was a screen .

div.stage: Knox appears somewhat relieved . ) But it fell down in the midst of the struggle .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: But in heaven 's name why was this done to you ?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Searching for the lost letters . They knew I had taken them .Speaking gravely .So you see , I have earned those papers . And I have earned the right to say what shall be done with them . I shall give them to you , and you will use them in your speech this afternoon .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: I do n't want them .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Going to bell and ringing .Oh yes you do . They are more valuable right now than anything else in the world .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Shaking his head .I wish it had n't happened .

lg.stage: Returning to him , pausing by his chair , and caressing his hair .
lg.l: What ?

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: This morning — your recovering the letters . I had adjusted myself to their loss , and the loss of the fight , and the finding of — you .

div.stage: He reaches up , draws down her hand , and presses it to his lips . ) So — give them back to your father .
Margaret draws quickly away from him . ) ( Enter Man-servant at right rear .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Send Linda to me .

div.stage: Exit Man-servant .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: What are you doing ?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Sitting down .I am going to send Linda for them . They are still in my father 's house , hidden , of all places , behind Lincoln 's portrait . He will guard them safely , I know .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: With fervor .Margaret ! Margaret ! Do n't send for them . Let them go . I do n't want them .

div.stage: Rising and going toward her impulsively . ) ( Margaret rises and retreats , holding him off . ) I want you — you — you .
He catches her hand and kisses it . She tears it away from him , but tenderly .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Still retreating , roguishly and tenderly .Dear , dear man , I love to see you so . But it cannot be .

div.stage: Looking anxiously toward right rear . ) No , no , please , please sit down .
Enter Linda from right rear . She is dressed for the street .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Surprised .Where are you going ?

sp.speaker: { Linda }
sp.p: Tommy and the nurse and I were going down town . There is some shopping she wants to do .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Very good . But go first to my father 's house . Listen closely . In the library , behind the portrait of Lincoln — you know it ?Linda nods .You will find a packet of papers . It took me five seconds to put it there . It will take you no longer to get it . Let no one see you . Let it appear as though you had brought Tommy to see his grandmother and cheer her up . You know she is not feeling very well just now . After you get the papers , leave Tommy there and bring them immediately back to me . Step on a chair to the ledge of the bookcase , and reach behind the portrait . You should be back inside fifteen minutes . Take the car .

sp.speaker: { Linda }
sp.p: Tommy and the nurse are already in it , waiting for me .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Be careful . Be quick .

div.stage: Linda nods to each instruction and makes exit .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Bursting out passionately .This is madness . You are sacrificing yourself , and me . I do n't want them . I want you . I am tired . What does anything matter except love ? I have pursued ideals long enough . Now I want you .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Gravely .Ah , there you have expressed the pith of it . You will now forsake ideals for me —He attempts to interrupt .No , no ; not that I am less than an ideal . I have no silly vanity that way . But I want you to remain ideal , and you can only by going on — not by being turned back . Anybody can play the coward and assert they are fatigued . I could not love a coward . It was your strength that saved us last night . I could not have loved you as I do , now , had you been weak last night . You can only keep my love —

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Interrupting , bitterly .By foregoing it — for an ideal . Margaret , what is the biggest thing in the world ? Love . There is the greatest ideal of all .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Playfully .Love of man and woman ?

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: What else ?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Gravely .There is one thing greater — love of man for his fellowman .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Oh , how you turn my preachments back on me . It is a lesson . Nevermore shall I preach . Henceforth —

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Yes .

div.stage: Chalmers enters unobserved at left , pauses , and looks on .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Henceforth I love . Listen .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: You are overwrought . It will pass , and you will see your path straight before you , and know that I am right . You cannot run away from the fight .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: I can — and will . I want you , and you want me — the man 's and woman 's need for each other . Come , go with me — now . Let us snatch at happiness while we may .

div.stage: He arises , approaches her , and gets her hand in his . She becomes more complaisant , and , instead of repulsing him , is willing to listen and receive . ) As I have said , the fight will go on just the same . Scores of men , better men , stronger men , than I , will rise to take my place . Why do I talk this way ? Because I love you , love you , love you . Nothing else exists in all the world but love of you .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Melting and wavering .Ah , you flame , you flame .

div.stage: Chalmers utters an inarticulate cry of rage and rushes forward at Knox
Margaret and Knox are startled by the cry and discover Chalmer 's presence .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Confronting Chalmers and thrusting him slightly back from Knox , and continuing to hold him off from Knox .No , Tom , no dramatics , please . This excitement of yours is only automatic and conventional . You really do n't mean it . You do n't even feel it . You do it because it is expected of you and because it is your training . Besides , it is bad for your heart . Remember Dr. West 's warning —

div.stage: Chalmers , making an unusually violent effort to get at Knox , suddenly staggers weakly back , signs of pain on his face , holding a hand convulsively clasped over his heart . Margaret catches him and supports him to a chair , into which he collapses .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Muttering weakly .My heart ! My heart !

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Approaching .Can I do anything ?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Calmly .No ; it is all right . He will be better presently .

div.stage: She is bending over Chalmers , her hand on his wrist , when suddenly , as a sign he is recovering , he violently flings her hand off and straightens up .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Undecidedly .I shall go now .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: No . You will wait until Linda comes back . Besides , you can n't run away from this and leave me alone to face it .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Hurt , showing that he will stay .I am not a coward .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: In a stifled voice that grows stronger .Yes ; wait I have a word for you .

div.stage: He pauses a moment , and when he speaks again his voice is all right .

Witheringly . ) A nice specimen of a reformer , I must say . You , who babbled yesterday about theft . The most high , righteous and noble Ali Baba , who has come into the den of thieves and who is also a thief .
Mimicking Margaret . ) “ Ah , you flame , you flame ! ”
In his natural voice . ) I should call you ; you thief , you thief , you wife-stealer , you .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Coolly .I should scarcely call it theft .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Sneeringly .Yes ; I forgot . You mean it is not theft for him to take what already belongs to him .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Not quite that — but in taking what has been freely offered to him .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: You mean you have so forgotten your womanhood as to offer —

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Just that . Last night . And Mr. Knox did himself the honor of refusing me .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Bursting forth .You see , nothing else remains , Margaret .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Twittingly .Ah , “ Margaret . ”

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Ignoring him .The situation is intolerable .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: EmphaticallyIt is intolerable . Do n't you think you had better leave this house ? Every moment of your presence dishonors it .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Do n't talk of honor , Tom .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: I make no excuses for myself . I fancy I never fooled you very much . But at any rate I never used my own house for such purposes .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Springing at him .You cur !

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Interposing .No ; do n't . His heart .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Mimicking Margaret .No dramatics , please .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Plaintively , looking from one man to the other .Men are so strangely and wonderfully made . What am I to do with the pair of you ? Why wo n't you reason together like rational human beings ?

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Bitterly gay , rising to his feet .Yes ; let us come and reason together . Be rational . Sit down and talk it over like civilized humans . This is not the stone age . Be reassured , Mr. Knox . I wo n't brain you . Margaret —

div.stage: Indicating chair ,) Sit down . Mr. Knox —
Indicating chair . ) Sit down .
All three seat themselves , in a triangle . ) Behold the problem — the ever ancient and ever young triangle of the playwright and the short story writer — two men and a woman .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: True , and yet not true . The triangle is incomplete . Only one of the two men loves the woman .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: And I am that man .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: I fancy you 're right .

div.stage: Nodding his head . ) But how about the woman ?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: She loves one of the two men .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: And what are you going to do about it ?

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Judicially .She has not yet indicated the man .

div.stage: Margaret is about to indicate Knox . ) Be careful , Madge . Remember who is Tommy 's father .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Tom , honestly , remembering what the last years have been can you imagine that I love you ?

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: I 'm afraid I 've not — er — not flamed sufficiently .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: You have possibly spoken nearer the truth than you dreamed . I married you , Tom , hoping great things of you . I hoped you would be a power for good —

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Politics again . When will women learn they must leave politics alone ?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: And also , I hoped for love . I knew you did n't love me when we married , but I hoped for it to come .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: And — er — may I be permitted to ask if you loved me ?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: No ; but I hoped that , too , would come .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: It was , then , all a mistake .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Yes ; yours , and mine , and my father 's .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: We have sat down to reason this out , and we get nowhere . Margaret and I love each other . Your triangle breaks .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: It is n't a triangle after all . You forget Tommy . { Knox }Petulantly .Make it four-sided , then , but let us come to some conclusion . { Chalmers }Reflecting .Ah , it is more than that . There is a fifth side . There are the stolen letters which Madge has just this morning restolen from her father . Whatever settlement takes place , they must enter into it .

div.stage: Changing his tone . ) Look here , Madge , I am a fool . Let us talk sensibly , you and Knox and I. Knox , you want my wife . You can have her — on one consideration . sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Everything ?

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Everything . Forgive and forget You know .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: You will forgive my — I — this — this adultery ?

sp.p: Doggedly .I 'll forgive anything for the letters . I 've played fast and loose with you , Madge , and I fancy your playing fast and loose only evens things up . What I want is the letters . Is it agreed ?

div.stage: Margaret seems to hesitate .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Pleadingly .Margaret .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: { Chalmers }Testily .Am I not giving you each other ? What more do you want ? Tommy stays with me . If you want Tommy , then stay with me , but you must give up the letters .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: I shall not go with Mr. Knox . I shall not give up the letters . I shall remain with Tommy .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: So far as I am concerned , Knox does n't count in this . I want the letters and I want Tommy . If you do n't give them up , I 'll divorce you on statutory grounds , and no woman , so divorced , can keep her child . In any event , I shall keep Tommy .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Speaking steadily and positively .Listen , Tom ; and you , too , Howard . I have never for a moment entertained the thought of giving up the letters . I may have led you to think so , but I wanted to see just how low , you , Tom , could sink . I saw how low you — all of you — this morning sank . I have learned — much . Where is this fine honor , Tom , which put you on a man-killing rage a moment ago ? You 'll barter it all for a few scraps of paper , and forgive and forget adultery which does not exist —

div.stage: Chalmers laughs skeptically . ) — though I know when I say it you will not believe me . At any rate , I shall not give up the letters . Not if you do take Tommy away from me . Not even for Tommy will I sacrifice all the people . As I told you this morning , there are two million Tommys , child-laborers all , who cannot be sacrificed for Tommy 's sake or anybody 's sake .
Chalmers shrugs his shoulders and smiles in ridicule .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Surely , Margaret , there is a way out for us . Give up the letters . What are they ?— only scraps of paper . Why match them against happiness — our happiness ?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: But as you told me yourself , those scraps of paper represent the happiness of millions of lives . It is not our happiness that is matched against some scraps of paper . It is our happiness against millions of lives — like ours . All these millions have hearts , and loves , and desires , just like ours .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: But it is a great social and cosmic process . It does not depend on one man . Kill off , at this instant , every leader of the people , and the process will go on just the same . The people will come into their own . Theft will be unseated . It is destiny . It is the process . Nothing can stop it .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: But it can be retarded .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: You and I are no more than straws in relation to it . We cannot stop it any more than straws can stop an ocean tide . We mean nothing — except to each other , and to each other we mean all the world .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Sadly and tenderly .All the world and immortality thrown in .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Breaking in .Nice situation , sitting here and listening to a strange man woo my wife in terms of sociology and scientific slang .

div.stage: Both Margaret and Knox ignore him .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Dear , I want you so .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Despairingly .Oh ! It is so hard to do right !

Tommy . He will give Tommy for them .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: No ; emphatically no . If she wants Tommy she can stay on ; but she must give up the letters . If she wants you she may go ; but she must give up the letters .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Pleading for a decision .Margaret .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Howard . Do n't tempt me and press me . It is hard enough as it is .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Standing up .I 've had enough of this . The thing must be settled , and I leave it to you , Knox . Go on with your love-making . But I wo n't be a witness to it . Perhaps I — er — retard the — er — the flame process . You two must make up your minds , and you can do it better without me . I am going to get a drink and settle my nerves . I 'll be back in a minute .

div.stage: He moves toward exit to right . ) She will yield , Knox . Be warm , be warm .
Pausing in doorway . ) Ah , you flame ! Flame to some purpose . ( Exit Chalmers .
Knox rests his head despairingly on his hand , and Margaret , pausing and looking at him sadly for a moment , crosses to him , stands beside him , and caresses his hair .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: It is hard , I know , dear . And it is hard for me as well .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: It is so unnecessary .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: No , it is necessary . What you said last night , when I was weak , was wise . We cannot steal from my child —

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: But if he gives you Tommy ? Margaret

div.stage: Shaking her head . ) Nor can we steal from any other woman 's child — from all the children of all the women . And other things I heard you say , and you were right . We cannot live by ourselves alone . We are social animals . Our good and our ill — all is tied up with all humanity .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Catching her hand and caressing it .I do not follow you . I hear your voice , but I do not know a word you say . Because I am loving your voice — and you . I am so filled with love that there is no room for anything else . And you , who yesterday were so remote and unattainable , are so near and possible , so immediately possible . All you have to do is to say the word , one little word . Say it .— Say it .

div.stage: He carries her hand to his lips and holds it there .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Wistfully .I should like to . I should like to . But I can n't .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: You must .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: There are other and greater things that say must to me . Oh , my dear , have you forgotten them ? Things you yourself have spoken to me — the great stinging things of the spirit , that are greater than you and I , greater even than our love .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: I exhaust my arguments — but still I love you .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: And I love you for it .

div.stage: Chalmers enters from right , and sees Margaret still caressing Knox 's hair .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: With mild elation , touched with sarcasm .Ah , I see you have taken my advice , and reached a decision .

div.stage: They do not answer . Margaret moves slowly away and seats herself . ) ( Knox remains with head bowed on hand . ) No ?
Margaret shakes her head . ) Well , I 've thought it over , and I 've changed my terms . Madge , go with Knox , take Tommy with you .
Margaret wavers , but Knox , head bowed on hand , does not see her . ) There will be no scandal . I 'll give you a proper divorce . And you can have Tommy .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Suddenly raising his head , joyfully , pleadingly .Margaret !

div.stage: Margaret is swayed , but does not speak .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: You and I never hit it off together any too extraordinarily well , Madge ; but I 'm not altogether a bad sort . I am easy-going . I always have been easy-going . I 'll make everything easy for you now . But you see the fix I am in . You love another man , and I simply must regain those letters . It is more important than you realize .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Incisively .You make me realize how important those letters are .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Give him the letters , Margaret

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: So she has n't turned them over to you yet ?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: No ; I still have them .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Give them to him .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Selling out for a petticoat . A pretty reformer . { Knox }Proudly .

sp.speaker: A better lover
sp.p: { Margaret }To Chalmers .He is weak to-day . What of it ? He was strong last night . He will win back his strength again . It is human to be weak . And in his very weakness now , I have my pride , for it is the weakness of love . God knows I have been weak , and I am not ashamed of it . It was the weakness of love . It is hard to stifle one 's womanhood always with morality .Quickly .But do not mistake , Tom . This of mine is no conventional morality . I do not care about nasty gossipy tongues and sensation-mongering sheets ; nor do I care what any persons of all the persons I know , would say if I went away with Mr. Knox this instant . I would go , and go gladly and proudly with him , divorce or no divorce , scandal or scandal triple-fold — if — if no one else were hurt by what I did .To Knox .Howard , I tell you that I would go with you now , in all willingness and joy , with May-time and the songs of all singing birds in my heart — were it not for the others . But there is a higher morality . We must not hurt those others . We dare not steal our happiness from them . The future belongs to them , and we must not , dare not , sacrifice that future nor give it in pledge for our own happiness . Last night I came to you . I was weak — yes ; more than that — I was ignorant . I did not know , even as late as last night , the monstrous vileness , the consummate wickedness of present-day conditions . I learned that today , this morning , and now . I learned that the morality of the Church was a pretense . Far deeper than it , and vastly more powerful , was the morality of the dollar . My father , my family , my husband , were willing to condone what they believed was my adultery . And for what ? For a few scraps of paper that to them represented only the privilege to plunder , the privilege to steal from the people .

div.stage: To Chalmers . ) Here are you , Tom , not only willing and eager to give me into the arms of the man you believe my lover , but you throw in your boy — your child and mine — to make it good measure and acceptable . And for what ? Love of some woman ?— any woman ? No . Love of humanity ? No . Love of God ? No . Then for what ? For the privilege of perpetuating your stealing from the people — money , bread and butter , hats , shoes , and stockings — for stealing all these things from the people .

To Knox . ) Now , and at last , do I realize how stern and awful is the fight that must be waged — the fight in which you and I , Howard , must play our parts and play them bravely and uncomplainingly — you as well as I , but I even more than you . This is the den of thieves . I am a child of thieves . All my family is composed of thieves . I have been fed and reared on the fruits of thievery . I have been a party to it all my life . Somebody must cease from this theft , and it is I . And you must help me , Howard .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Emitting a low long whistle .Strange that you never went into the suffragette business . With such speech-making ability you would have been a shining light .

sp.speaker: { Knox }
sp.p: Sadly .The worst of it is , Margaret , you are right . But it is hard that we cannot be happy save by stealing from the happiness of others . Yet it hurts , deep down and terribly , to forego you .Margaret thanks him with her eyes .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: Sarcastically .Oh , believe me , I am not too anxious to give up my wife . Look at her . She 's a pretty good woman for any man to possess .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Tom , I 'll accept a quiet divorce , marry Mr. Knox , and take Tommy with me — on one consideration .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: And what is that ?

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: That I retain the letters . They are to be used in his speech this afternoon .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: No they 're not .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Whatever happens , do whatever worst you can possibly do , that speech will be given this afternoon . Your worst to me will be none too great a price for me to pay .

sp.speaker: { Chalmers }
sp.p: No letters , no divorce , no Tommy , nothing .

sp.speaker: { Margaret }
sp.p: Then will you compel me to remain here . I have done nothing wrong , and I do n't imagine you will make a scandal .

Some day , soon , like the horse , it will quit We can afford to wait . It wo n't be long .
